Title: Oil Sands Monitoring Cumulative Effects Scientist
Job_Description: Are you are an environmental scientist with a strong interest in the theory, design and management of complex systems? If so, the Environmental Monitoring and Science Division of Environment and Parks has an exciting opportunity for you!  The Oil Sands Monitoring Cumulative Effects Scientist is responsible for the transition to an integrated, adaptive cumulative effects monitoring system in the Alberta Oil Sands. You will analyze changes in environmental condition to inform reporting and adaptation in monitoring design and to evaluate change relative to predicted trajectories.  To be successful in this role you will have:  Expert knowledge and experience of the application of an adaptive systems approach to monitoring design. Expert understanding and experience of the study design and statistical tools and techniques that support the detection of environmental change Broad familiarity with the diverse scientific disciplines that are engaged in oil sands monitoring.  You will work with EMSD leadership, EMSD staff and scientists, and oil sands monitoring scientists to ensure that monitoring is integrated across media and disciplines according to clearly articulated environmental response pathways and is designed to detect ecologically and culturally relevant change. You must effectively communicate complex scientific issues, concepts and results to a wide range of expert and non-expert audiences to ensure government, industry, and communities can understand and apply the information generated by oil sands monitoring programs.  Your Work Environment: You will primarily be working in an office setting located in Calgary. You will have frequent contact with EMSD staff and scientists in Calgary and Edmonton, other government departments, external stakeholders and communities, and research teams working within and across post-secondary institutions, the Federal Government, scientific organizations, aboriginal communities and industry. Some travel will be required.  Qualifications  The position requires: A Ph.D. in environmental science and 2 years of experience in scientific study design, adaptive monitoring systems design, cumulative effects evaluation, environmental effects monitoring or advanced numerical analysis of large environmental data sets. Equivalencies such as M.Sc. and 4 years of experience as described will be considered.  Assets:  Strong communication and interpersonal skills to build and develop collaborative relationships and deliver information to EMSD leadership, the scientific community and key stakeholders; Ability to influence and lead change processes including conflict resolution and mediation skills; A record of publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals commensurate with established peers with a similar level of experience; Familiarity with the Canadian Oil Sands industry; Familiarity with relevant environmental legislation, regulation, and policy.  Competencies Competencies are behaviours that are essential to reach our goals in serving Albertans. We encourage you to have an in depth understanding of the competencies that are required for this opportunity and to be prepared to demonstrate them during the recruitment process. The links below will assist you with understanding competencies: http://www.psc.alberta.ca/Practitioners/?file=learning/apscompetencies/titlepage&cf=9  http://www.psc.alberta.ca/learning/apscompetencies/apscomp-self-assessment-questionnaire.pdf  Your competencies: Agility - Ability to identify, anticipate, and analyze complex issues and to adapt concepts to novel applications; ability to adapt to new information and constraints. Drive for Results - Ability to successfully manage multiple projects, meet timelines and work under pressure. Build Collaborative Environments - Ability to bridge professional disagreement and to identify common ground. Develop Networks - Build capacity by collaborating with colleagues within and outside of government and in the community. Systems Thinking - Ability to identify critical pathways within complex relationships between environmental pressures and environmental outcomes; ability to apply a systems approach to extract actionable information from environmental monitoring. Creative Problem Solving - Apply systems and approaches developed in other disciplines (e.g. social sciences, engineering) to evaluate environmental change and to manage the monitoring system. Job_Description: Position Description Location: University of Calgary, Cumming School of Medicine Area: Medical Genomics/Bioinformatics Start Date: September 1, 2018 Silent Genomes is a Genome Canada/CIHR recently funded Large-Scale Applied Research Project focused on reducing health care disparities and improving diagnostic success for children with genetic diseases from Indigenous populations. Precision diagnosis, a sub-activity of the Silent Genomes, has the main goal to bring state-of-the-art whole genome sequencing approaches to at least 200 Indigenous families across Canada affected by a suspected genetic disease. The precision diagnosis sub-activity is organized in two levels: (Level 1) application of tried and established semi-automated bioinformatics approach to analyze whole genome sequencing data, and (Level 2) testing and development of new bioinformatics approaches to reach beyond current state-of-the-field, and to facilitate identification of genetic causes in patients who remain undiagnosed after Level 1 analysis. The two teams collaborate very closely. A fully funded PhD position is available for a highly motivated student with strong interest in medical genomics/bioinformatics and innovative strategies to improve current whole genome sequencing approaches to increase the diagnostic potential of this test for the Silent Genomes effort. The PhD candidate is expected to test existing and develop comprehensive genomics approaches to improve diagnostic potential of high throughput sequencing methods. The PhD candidate is expected to work in close collaboration with the post-doctoral fellow(s), Activity 2 co-lead(s), as well as the rest of the Silent Genomes team, which will require quarterly travels within Canada. Publication of peer-reviewed papers in high-impact scientific journals is an expectation of this position. Applicants who either self-identify as Indigenous and/or are interested in Indigenous health are particularly encouraged to apply for this position. Qualifications: MSc/BSc degree in Computer Science, Bioinformatics, Genetics or related disciplines MD/PhD Leaders in Medicine candidate(s) with keen interest in Indigenous health and research will be given a priority Experience with genomics/bioinformatics/ programming languages (e.g. Python, Perl) is highly desirable Leadership in developing and executing research projects leading to publication is desirable Proven ability to work in a confidential environment is a must Successful completion of Tri-Council Policy Statement (TCPS) online tutorial (may be completed upon recruitment) Successful completion of an Indigenous Cultural Safety Course (may be completed upon recruitment).
